citation.article-title: Emended descriptions of Clostridium acetobutylicum and Clostridium beijerinckii, and descriptions of Clostridium saccharoperbutylacetonicum sp. nov. and Clostridium saccharobutylicum sp. nov.
citation.source: International Journal of Systematic and Evolutionary Microbiology

p.s: Description of Clostridium saccharoperbutylacetonicum sp. nov.

Clostridium saccharoperbutylacetonicum (sac.cha.ro.per.bu.tyl.a.ce.to'ni.cum. Gr. n. saccharon sugar juice ; Gr. pron. per throughout; N.L. n. butylum butanol; N.L. adj. acetonicus acetonic; N.L. adj. saccharoperbutylacetonicum denoting the production of a large amount of butanol and acetone from sugar)
C. saccharoperbutylacetonicum was first named and described by Hongo (1960) in US patent no. 2945786.

The species status of C. saccharoperbutylacetonicum has now been firmly established by 16S rRNA genesequence analysis (Keis et al., 1995) and DNA-DNA reassociation (Johnson et al., 1997), and, since this name is in widespread use in the scientific literature, we recommend that it be validated.
The original description by Hongo (1960) has been incorporated in the description provided below.
Strain N1-4 was deposited by Hongo & Murata in the American Type Culture Collection as strain ATCC 13564, along with its derivatives N1-4 (HMT) (ATCC 27021T) and N1-504 (ATCC 27022).
Cells in most broth cultures consist of straight, short and long rods with rounded ends, measuring 0.4-0.8 μm x3.1-6.2 μm.
Rods occur singly, or occasionally in pairs, and are motile by means of peritrichous flagella.
They are initially phase-dark and Gram-positive, becoming Gram-negative in older cultures.
Towards the end of exponential growth, the rod-shaped cells usually begin to accumulate granulose.
These morphological changes are typically associated with the metabolic shift from acid production to solvent production.
Endospores are oval, measuring 0.8-1.5 μm x 1.6-2.2 μm.
Existing strains sporulate poorly on most common laboratory culture media.
Colonies on CBMagar are 2-3 mm in diameter, domed, white and have smooth surfaces and entire}undulated margins.
The species is mesophilic, optimum growth for solvent production occurring between 25 and 35 °C; the optimum pH range is between pH 5.6 and pH 6.7.
Catalase, oxidase and indole are not produced.
The strains are resistant to rifampicin (100 ng).
Aesculin and gelatin are hydrohydrolysed.
Nitrate is not reduced to nitrite.
Ammonia is produced from nitrite.

The results for the production of hydrogen sulphide are as follows: negative from peptone-containing medium; negative or weakly positive from the reduction of sulphites ; and positive from the reduction of thiosulphates.
Digestion of coagulated albumin is very weak or negative.

Strains ferment arabinose, xylose, glucose, mannose, cellobiose, lactose, maltose, saccharose, D-arabitol, L-arabitol, mannitol, melibiose, methyl-glucopyranoside, raffinose, salicin, trehalose, turanose, amygdalin, starch, glycogen, dextrin, pectin, melezitose and inulin.
The utilization of the latter two sugars is in contrast to the original description given in the patent by Hongo (1960).
The sugars ribose and glycerol were not utilized and weak fermentation was observed with rhamnose.
Strain N1-4 was able to ferment sorbitol, dulcitol and inositol, but strain N1-504 was unable to utilize these alcohol sugars.
No curd formation of milk occurs during the ®rst 48 h and no ribo¯avin is produced (Johnson et al., 1997).
The G+C content of the DNA (Tm) is 31 mol% (Hongo et al., 1966).
Fermentation products include acetic and butyric acids, acetone, butanol, ethanol, CO2 and H2.
These industrial strains were used in the applied fermentation process for the production of the solvents acetone, butanol and ethanol from a variety of sugar- and starchbased substrates.
Commercial production of solvents commonly used various types of molasses mash supplemented with nitrogen in the form of ammonium salts and organic nitrogen.

Typically, industrial fermentations utilized molasses containing 4-6% fermentable sugars at temperatures of 25-35 °C for 48-72 h, giving a final pH of 5.5-8.0, solvent yields of 27-34% and solvent concentrations of 15-17 g l-1 (maximum 19 g l-1); the proportion of butanol ranged from 73 to 85%.
Corn mash typically required longer fermentation times and produced significantly lower yields and concentrations of solvents.

More detailed information on solvent ratios, concentrations and yields for both sugar-based and starch-based substrates with two strains belonging to this species is available in a recent publication by Shaheen et al. (2000).
Since the ATCC 13564 strain has been deaccessioned, it is recommended that the type strain for this species should be ATCC 27021T.
